ForceField: Impact Detection Sensors for Hurling/Camogie

Developed a device and accompanying system to monitor and reduce concussion risks in hurling and camogie.

The Problem

  • 2.23 potentially concussive events per inter-county hurling match
  • Over 75% of players displaying concussive symptoms not removed from the game
  • 3 times more potentially concussive events in hurling than in rugby

Our Solution: ForceField

An impact detection sensor combined with an app for continuous monitoring of players' head impacts. The data collected is transformed into actionable information for real-time decision-making regarding player well-being.

System Workflow

  1. Data Collection: The sensors on players' helmets, equipped with IMUs and ADXL375 high G force accelerometers, continuously monitor and collect impact data.
  2. ESP-NOW Communication: Using the ESP32 C3 microcontroller, each sensor transmits its data using ESP-NOW, a protocol designed for direct device-to-device communication. This allows for quick, low-power data transfer between sensors.
  3. Access Point Node: An access point node, positioned on the side of the pitch, receives data from all active sensors using ESP-NOW.
  4. WiFi Transmission: The access point node connects to the user's phone over WiFi, establishing a bridge between the ESP-NOW network and the mobile device.
  5. Web Socket Communication: Once connected to the phone, the access point uses web sockets to send the aggregated sensor data to our mobile app in real-time.
  6. Data Processing and Display: Our custom-developed mobile app receives the data, processes it, and displays it graphically in real-time. This allows coaches, medics, or parents to monitor impact events as they occur.
  7. Decision Support: Based on the processed data, the app provides actionable information to support decisions about player safety, such as recommending when a player should be assessed for potential concussion.

Technical Details

  • Custom PCB design with ESP32 C3 microcontroller
  • Onboard IMUs and ADXL375 high G force accelerometers
  • Wireless charging circuitry using Texas Instruments battery charge discharge IC
  • Data transmission using ESP-NOW protocol and WiFi
  • Custom mobile app for real-time data visualization

Development Process

  • Custom PCB design and assembly using a DIY reflow oven
  • 3D printed custom cases based on our own 3D scans of hurling helmets
  • Developed custom transition protocols
  • Rigorous testing, including throwing the device on tarmacadam and trialing in a competitive club camogie match

Current Status and Future Plans

  • Successfully tested in a competitive club match
  • Planning to approach county development squads for more rigorous testing
  • Engaging with manufacturers like the Advanced Manufacturing Institute for mass production
  • Reaching out to high-performance coaches to integrate technology into senior club and inter-county squads

Why ForceField?

  • Addresses a critical need in hurling and camogie
  • Adaptable to the unique shape of hurling helmets
  • More accessible price point compared to existing solutions
  • Potential for integration with GAA regulations, similar to World Rugby's approach
